nodes.text: The Naive Bayes classifier is an effective and reliable method for detecting spam emails on a combined dataset
Spam email detection is an important problem because unsolicited emails harm communication and pose security risks
Naive Bayes operates by applying Bayes theorem with the conditional independence assumption and is computationally efficient for large text datasets
This study applies the Naive Bayes algorithm to a combined dataset to evaluate its performance for spam filtering
The combined dataset merges the 2007 TREC Public Spam Corpus and the Enron-Spam dataset into 83,446 labeled emails (43,910 spam, 39,538 ham)
Naive Bayes uses prior probabilities, likelihoods of words given class, multiplication of word likelihoods, and Laplace smoothing to avoid zero probabilities
The classifier represents emails using Bag-of-Words after text cleaning and tokenization (remove punctuation/stopwords, lowercase, tokenize, count frequencies)
The dataset was randomly split 80% train (66,756 emails) and 20% test (16,690 emails) while preserving class proportions
A 5-fold cross-validation was used to select the best model before final evaluation
Class distribution after split: training 35,128 spam / 31,630 ham; test 8,782 spam / 7,908 ham
Cross-validation accuracies for folds were 0.9733, 0.9766, 0.9762, 0.9759, 0.9755 with average ~0.9751 indicating stable performance
The model selected from Fold 2, trained on full training set and evaluated on test set, achieved overall accuracy 97.82%
Per-class test results: ham 7,800 correctly classified, 108 misclassified (ham accuracy 98.64%); spam 8,526 correctly classified, 256 misclassified (spam accuracy 97.08%)
Aggregate classification metrics on test set: precision ~0.98, recall ~0.98, F1-score ~0.98 (macro and weighted averages), support 16,690
High and balanced precision, recall, and F1 across classes indicate the Naive Bayes model effectively distinguishes spam from ham on this dataset

Conclusion: Naive Bayes is a promising, efficient tool for spam detection and suitable for practical filtering systems; future work could explore hybrid models and incorporate contextual/semantic analysis
